title: Big Brother reboot set to divide viewers amid rumours it WON'T be aired live
text:
Channel Seven's reboot of Big Brother is set to divide viewers, with rumours swirling the 2020 series won't be aired live and a new format will be introduced.

According to TV Blackbox, the new season of Big Brother will be filmed in April but won't air on Channel Seven until August.

In the upcoming reboot, the public will also reportedly be excluded from the voting process, with the contestants instead deciding who stays and who goes.

Oh, no! Channel Seven's reboot of Big Brother is set to divide viewers, with rumours swirling the 2020 series won't be aired live and a new format will be introduced. Pictured: Former host Gretel Killeen and housemate Simon 'Hotdogs' Deering on July 10, 2005

TV Blackbox also reported that, due to cost-cutting measures, the show will be filmed in a 'warehouse' instead of the traditional house setting.

Big Brother, which last aired in Australia five years ago, was originally filmed in a mansion on the Gold Coast, but the building has since been destroyed by arsonists.

Meanwhile, former host Gretel Killeen will also not be returning to the franchise because her 'price was deemed too high'.

Changes: In the upcoming reboot, the public will reportedly be excluded from the voting process, with the contestants instead deciding who stays and who goes. Pictured: Big Brother housemates on July 27, 2004

The idea of incorporating a voiceover instead of an actual host is being considered, according to industry sources.

Gretel previously hosted Big Brother for seven seasons on Channel 10 before being replaced by Kyle Sandilands and Jackie 'O' Henderson in 2008.

Channel Nine's revival, which aired between 2012 and 2014, was hosted by Sonia Kruger.

Moving on? Former host Gretel Killeen (pictured) will not be returning to the franchise because her 'price was deemed too high', according to industry website TV Blackbox

Earlier this month, it was confirmed that Big Brother Australia will be returning for a new season in 2020.

Channel Seven will reportedly finance the show using the budget originally allocated for the now-cancelled current affairs program Sunday Night.

Production company Endemol Shine has already opened applications for Big Brother 2020 and potential housemates can apply online.
